author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Ida Moves Through the Cayman Islands
description: The latest storm in a busy season could strengthen into a major hurricane and is expected to reach Louisiana this weekend.
content: Tropical Storm Ida moved through the Cayman Islands on Thursday and could reach the northern Gulf Coast of the United States over the weekend as a major hurricane, just days after forming as the ninth named storm of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, the National Hurricane Center said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Hartsdale, N.Y., and a six-bedroom in Montclair, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Female Hummingbirds Avoid Harassment by Looking Like Males
description: Among white-necked Jacobin hummingbirds, those with plumage that resembles colors found on males get harassed less.
content: An adult female white-necked Jacobin hummingbird is no stranger to invisible labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Walker
title: Conservative Reforms Worked Wonders in Blue Wisconsin
description: Act 10’s reforms to weaken public-sector unions helped both schools and taxpayers.
content: A caseworker once came into my office with tears in her eyes, offering to take a cut in pay to keep her newer colleagues on the job. Milwaukee County, where I served as the top executive at the time, was forced to lay off staff members after deep cuts in state aid to local governments and schools before I became governor of Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: Children may not immediately understand the title “Dynamic H2O,” but they don’t need to have studied chemistry to warm to this exhibition’s cool topic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the BMW Championship, Sam Burns Is Steady Once Again
description: The American golfer has now shot 64 in four of his last eight rounds on the PGA Tour dating to early August.
content: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Sam Burns, who won his first PGA Tour event in May, made two birdies in his first four holes during the first round of the BMW Championship on Thursday. It was a good start for Burns, a lesser-known tour pro competing alongside the galaxy of top golfers at the tournament, which is the second of three events in the season-ending FedEx Cup playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Remaking the Economy
description: Democrats in Congress are putting together an ambitious bill to advance Biden’s domestic agenda. Here’s a guide.
content: President Biden’s domestic agenda seems to be back on track in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. evacuations slow because of bottlenecks at bases, the Pentagon says.
description: The Pentagon flew out 13,400 people from Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul in the past 24 hours, military officials said on Thursday, a sharp decline from the past few days largely because receiving bases in the Middle East are again filling up. Of that 24-hour total, coalition flights carried out 8,300 passengers — about the same as in recent days.
content: The Pentagon flew out 13,400 people from Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul in the past 24 hours, military officials said on Thursday, a sharp decline from the past few days largely because receiving bases in the Middle East are again filling up. Of that 24-hour total, coalition flights carried out 8,300 passengers — about the same as in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Berlinger
title: What’s Next for ‘Jeopardy!’ Fans?
description: A search to replace Alex Trebek continues. The next generation of viewers have some thoughts.
content: After Mike Richards quit his new gig a mere nine days after being announced successor to Alex Trebek, the iconic host of “Jeopardy!” who died in November of last year, fans were left in limbo. His decision to step down came after The Ringer revealed Mr. Richards’s past offensive and sexist remarks made years ago on a podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Turbow
title: ‘He Knows It All Because He’s Seen It All’
description: Steve Vucinich’s 54th and final season with the Athletics has pushed the team’s equipment manager past Connie Mack for the longest run in franchise history. He has stories to spare.
content: Steve Vucinich has been around the A’s for so long, has known so many people and seen so many things, that when he starts talking about the old days, one story seems to flow into the next. It almost has to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Oregon’s strict mandates.
content: Throughout most of the coronavirus pandemic, Oregon has been a success story, ranking 46th in the nation in deaths per capita as it maintained some of the country’s most stringent restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Madeleine Ngo
title: Bottlenecks at an adult tricycle company illustrate continuing economic challenges.
description: Catrike has 500 of its three-wheeled bikes sitting in its workshop in Orlando, Fla., nearly ready to be sent to expectant dealers. The recumbent trikes have been waiting for months for rear derailleurs, a small but crucial part that is built in Taiwan.
content: Catrike has 500 of its three-wheeled bikes sitting in its workshop in Orlando, Fla., nearly ready to be sent to expectant dealers. The recumbent trikes have been waiting for months for rear derailleurs, a small but crucial part that is built in Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Wants Trump to Stop Complimenting the Taliban
description: “You don’t have to give the Taliban credit for anything — they’re the Taliban!” Meyers said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: 54 Years Late, Dorothy Parker Finally Gets a Tombstone
description: The beloved author wrote many witty epitaphs but never suggested where her remains should end up. Her fans helped complete her ashes’ odyssey.
content: Dorothy Parker was born during a hurricane. So the poet, known for her mordant wit, might have gotten a dark chuckle that Hurricane Henri derailed plans for the long-in-coming unveiling of her headstone at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx last Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why Vaccine Mandates for Teachers Have Been a Harder Sell Than Mask Mandates for Kids
description: The most powerful teachers’ union president in America discusses school reopening, mask mandates and vaccine-or-test requirements.
content: As the pandemic has pushed the country into a debate about when and how to reopen schools, Randi Weingarten has faced the ire of parents, teachers, school boards and — of course — Fox News. Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, leads a union of 1.7 million educators across the nation. She’s been on the hook for pressing to keep schools closed last fall and supporting mask mandates in classrooms this year. And most recently, she drew criticism from her members when she personally endorsed a vaccine mandate and promised to work with states and school boards that are seeking to enact vaccine mandates or vaccinate-or-test requirements for teachers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Egner
title: Nick Mohammed Has Been Faking It on ‘Ted Lasso’
description: The British actor and soccer non-fan scored his first Emmy nomination playing a sharp soccer coach in the hit Apple TV+ comedy.
content: Voting is underway for the 73rd Primetime Emmys, and this week we’re talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 19 on CBS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Lily Topples the World’ Review: What Goes Up
description: A gifted YouTuber gets a superficial profile in this lackadaisical documentary.
content: If you’re not one of the more than 3 million subscribers to Lily Hevesh’s YouTube channel, then you may be unaware of what it takes to become a world-famous domino artist. “Lily Topples the World” aims to enlighten you; but this undisciplined, curiously shallow documentary from Jeremy Workman might leave you with more questions than answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tony Finau’s Perseverance a Lesson in Overcoming Setbacks
description: The American golfer had eight runner-up finishes across five winless years until he won the Northern Trust on Monday. His rivals couldn’t be happier.
content: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Unbridled euphoria unfolds alongside haunting discontent routinely in the crucible of professional golf, most conspicuously at the end of tournaments. A player wins an event and grins throughout a post-round interview on the final green. Steps away, the golfer who finished second faces probing questions about what went wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Why a 19th-Century Plan to Replace Black Labor with Chinese Labor Failed
description: The Mississippi Chinese and how race works in America.
content: In the late 1860s, just a few years after the end of the Civil War, a group of plantation owners in the Mississippi Delta began talking to one another about a labor problem. Newly freed Black people made up the majority of the agricultural work force, but they were going against the party of the South’s white establishment and voting Republican. Some were simply picking up and leaving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: R. Kelly Said He Liked ‘Young Girls,’ His Third Accuser Testifies
description: The third accuser to testify at the singer’s trial said Mr. Kelly described himself as a “genius” who should be allowed to do what he wanted.
content: Stephanie was 17 and out to dinner with R. Kelly and two rappers, she said, when Mr. Kelly said something that surprised her: He liked “young girls,” and he did not understand why people made such a big deal of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Older Tree Climbers
description: Should a father still be saving cats from trees when he’s over 70?
content: Andrew writes: My father is over 70, with serious back problems and arthritis in his hands, but he still rescues cats from trees. While it’s impressive that he can climb a 25-foot cedar and grapple with a terrified cat, I don’t think it’s worth the risk. My dad insists there’s no way he’ll get hurt. Please order him to stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: As Shootings Increased, N.Y.C Returned to Disputed Tactic: Gang Takedowns
description: The authorities are responding to a wave of gun violence. But their anti-gang tactics have long faced criticism for unfairly targeting young Black people.
content: A father was wounded while shielding his three children from gunfire at a car dealership. A teacher was killed on a morning dog walk when a gunman missed his target. And a baby in his stroller was mortally wounded when two men opened fire on a nighttime cookout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Candyman’ Review: Who Can Take a Sunrise, Sprinkle It With Blood?
description: The new take on the 1990s cult horror film returns the story to its old stomping ground, this time with Jordan Peele as a producer.
content: The first time Candyman, the hook-wielding ghoul, hit the big screen it was 1992 and he was making mincemeat out of people in Cabrini-Green, the troubled public housing development in Chicago. Since then, residents have left (or been moved out), and more than a dozen buildings have been razed. Forgettable sequels have come and gone, too, yet Candyman abides, cult film characters being a more enduring and certainly more prized commodity than affordable housing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Together’ Review: Love and Loathing in London
description: Sharon Horgan and James McAvoy play a battling couple trapped in lockdown in this theatrical pandemic drama.
content: Like an awful herald of what could lie in wait as future filmmakers grapple with our ongoing viral nightmare, Stephen Daldry’s “Together” is an almost punishing watch. That it’s bearable at all is entirely because of the superlative acting skills of James McAvoy and Sharon Horgan as an unnamed couple forced to endure an extended London lockdown. In place of a plot, we get a setup: They can’t stand the sight of each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Michael Levenson
title: U.S. Says 1,500 Americans Remain in Afghanistan as Evacuation Enters Final Days
description: The State Department is frantically trying to track down U.S. citizens. Tens of thousands of Afghan allies will all but certainly be left behind.
content: WASHINGTON — At least 1,500 American citizens remain in Afghanistan with just days left before the scheduled U.S. withdrawal from the country, but officials on Wednesday acknowledged the reality that tens of thousands of Afghan allies and others at high risk of Taliban reprisals would be left behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Emmett Till’s Enduring Legacy
description: Here is a look at who he was, the outrage at his murder and the acquittal of his killers, and how he has shaped the civil rights movement in America.
content: In late summer 1955, Mamie Till chose to lay the body of her only child, Emmett, in an open coffin, believing that “the whole nation had to bear witness to this” — this Black child of Chicago who had been murdered and mutilated by white men in Mississippi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor, Arya Sundaram and Melena Ryzik
title: Time’s Up C.E.O. Resigns Amid Crisis Over Cuomo Ties
description: The departure is the latest fallout from revelations that group leaders advised the former New York governor on handling harassment allegations.
content: The chief executive of Time’s Up, the prominent anti-harassment charity, resigned on Thursday, the latest fallout in a crisis that threatens the organization’s survival.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Curated sardines, a new guesthouse in Arles — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Larry Harlow, Influential Figure in Salsa, Dies at 82
description: He was born into a family of Jewish musicians, but he made his mark in Latin music, as a pianist, bandleader and producer.
content: Born into a family of musicians, Larry Harlow was probably destined for a music career from the start. But it was his walks to class at the High School of Music and Art in Upper Manhattan that put him onto his lifelong passion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Border Standoff Over Afghan Migrants Highlights E.U. Fears of New Influx
description: Belarus is accused of using migrants as a weapon against the European Union after a group of Afghans got trapped on its border with Poland, where the issue has become increasingly politicized.
content: BRUSSELS — A standoff that has trapped Afghan asylum seekers on the border between Belarus and Poland is a telling example of the European Union’s dilemma over migration, especially acute now with the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A State So Dry, Ranchers Are Selling Cows Before They Starve
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 26, 2021.
content: “You spend your entire life with these cattle. I can tell you, there’s going to be tears.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Kamala Harris Pledges U.S. Help for Afghan Women and Children
description: As she left Southeast Asia, the vice president also delivered a blunt message to China. The United States does not want conflict, she said, but on some issues, “we are going to speak up.”
content: HANOI — Vice President Kamala Harris said on Thursday that the United States would work with its allies to protect women and children in Afghanistan, as the Taliban takeover forced her to confront troubling historical parallels and diverted attention from her original mission on a five-day trip to Southeast Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: One California City’s Creative Drought Fix
description: The wine country town of Healdsburg is offering residents treated wastewater for their yards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: Wildfire Smoke Is Hurting Your Skin
description: A first-of-its-kind study links wildfires to skin damage. Here’s what you need to know.
content: Dr. Maria Wei, a professor of dermatology at the University of California San Francisco, was helping a student come up with a project about how the environment affects skin when she looked out her office window and saw the ash falling from the sky. It was the first day of the California Camp Fire — the 2018 wildfire that was, at the time, the state’s deadliest and most destructive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Backed by Nine Inch Nails, Halsey Connects Past and Future
description: On “If I Can’t Have Love, I Want Power,” the 26-year-old musician enlists a longtime role model and takes one step back from confessionals.
content: Halsey’s fourth album, “If I Can’t Have Love, I Want Power,” announces its character from its first sounds: slowly tolling piano arpeggios with a few notes flatted into dissonance. It’s an unmistakable echo of Nine Inch Nails’ “Hurt” from 1994, the year Halsey was born. The new song, “The Tradition,” opens a cross-generational, album-length collaboration with a longtime influence: Trent Reznor, who started Nine Inch Nails as a solo studio project in 1987, and Atticus Ross, his partner in Oscar-winning film scores and an official member of Nine Inch Nails since 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘No Man of God’ Review: Buddying Up to Bundy
description: The film dramatizes what it sees as the rapport between an F.B.I. profiler and the serial killer.
content: “No Man of God” can’t help but play like the special Ted Bundy episode of “Mindhunter” we haven’t gotten to see yet. The movie, directed by Amber Sealey, dramatizes what it sees as the rapport that developed between Bundy (Luke Kirby) and the F.B.I. profiler Bill Hagmaier (Elijah Wood), who visited Bundy in prison and tried to pick his brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘The Colony’ Review: Fertile Ground Goes to Waste
description: In this science fiction film, set generations after humans have destroyed Earth, an astronaut returns to the planet to see if it is habitable.
content: “The Colony,” a new sci-fi drama directed by Tim Fehlbaum, posits an Earth once rendered uninhabitable by climate change, pandemics and war. Years later, though the ruling elite has fled to another planet, they must reinvestigate Earth after their society becomes infertile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Matthew Stafford Wants His Hollywood Ending. So Do the Rams.
description: After 12 seasons in Detroit, the quarterback wanted out. The Los Angeles Rams, looking to move on from Jared Goff, saw in Stafford another shot at a championship run.
content: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — After Matthew Stafford, the Los Angeles Rams’ new quarterback, threw three interceptions this month in a joint practice with the Las Vegas Raiders, he and his teammates remained calm. Instead of pouting or slamming his helmet, he convened with his coaches to discuss what went wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Two New York judges ordered defendants to get vaccinated. Can they do that?
description: Orders by New York judges — one in the Bronx and one in Manhattan — that two defendants appearing in their courts get vaccinated raise important questions about the line between civic responsibility and civil liberties, legal observers say, though neither defendant appeared to object.
content: Orders by New York judges — one in the Bronx and one in Manhattan — that two defendants appearing in their courts get vaccinated raise important questions about the line between civic responsibility and civil liberties, legal observers say, though neither defendant appeared to object.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: At Two Summer Festivals, Offerings That Are Gloomy and Grim
description: The Salzburg Festival and the Ruhrtriennale host a series of theatrical pieces, both old and new, that seem to reflect our troubled time.
content: ESSEN, Germany — In the constellation of Europe’s performing arts festivals, few make a more contrasting pair than the Salzburg Festival and the Ruhrtriennale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Chris Buckley
title: Spies for Hire: China’s New Breed of Hackers Blends Espionage and Entrepreneurship
description: The state security ministry is recruiting from a vast pool of private-sector hackers who often have their own agendas and sometimes use their access for commercial cybercrime, experts say.
content: China’s buzzy high-tech companies don’t usually recruit Cambodian speakers, so the job ads for three well-paid positions with those language skills stood out. The ad, seeking writers of research reports, was placed by an internet security start-up in China’s tropical island-province of Hainan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: How Should the Fed Deal With Climate Change?
description: When the economy hits hard times, survey data shows, people are less likely to worry about the environment.
content: The climate crisis is at high risk of becoming an economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan halts 1.6 million doses of the Moderna vaccine over contamination worries.
description: The problem comes as the country, which initially struggled to get its inoculation program into full gear, confronts its worst wave of Covid-19 cases since the pandemic began.
content: TOKYO — The Japanese health authorities on Thursday announced that they would halt the use of over 1.6 million doses of Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine after some vaccination sites reported finding tainted vials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Mosquito State’ Review: Bugging Out
description: A Wall Street genius becomes the willing host to a colony of mosquitoes in this dreamily surreal horror movie.
content: Borne along on the whine of insects and a lead performance of surpassing strangeness, “Mosquito State” is a disquieting merger of body horror and social commentary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Kasulis Cho
title: Guam tries (and mostly fails) to lure tourists back with vaccines.
description: While much of the United States has returned to something resembling life before the coronavirus, the tiny American territory of Guam in the Western Pacific is stuck in time.
content: While much of the United States has returned to something resembling life before the coronavirus, the tiny American territory of Guam in the Western Pacific is stuck in time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Where Are Workers Making the Longest Commutes?
description: Commutes taking over 90 minutes in each direction increased by 45 percent from 2010 and 2019. Then came the pandemic.
content: Do you have a long commute to work? If it takes 90 minutes or more in each direction, congratulations, you’re part of a cohort known as “supercommuters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The Biden administration is being criticized for falling short on its pledge to provide vaccines to the world.
description: President Biden, who has pledged to fight the coronavirus pandemic by making the United States the “arsenal of vaccines” for the world, is under increasing criticism from public health experts, global health advocates and even Democrats in Congress who say he is nowhere near fulfilling his promise.
content: President Biden, who has pledged to fight the coronavirus pandemic by making the United States the “arsenal of vaccines” for the world, is under increasing criticism from public health experts, global health advocates and even Democrats in Congress who say he is nowhere near fulfilling his promise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins, Sharif Hassan, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Suicide Bombers in Kabul Kill Dozens, Including 13 U.S. Troops
description: Bombers struck a huge crowd outside the airport, killing at least 60 Afghan civilians in the waning days of the U.S. evacuation from Afghanistan.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two explosions killed dozens of people, including at least 13 U.S. troops, ripping through the crowds outside Afghanistan’s main airport on Thursday, just hours after Western governments had warned of an imminent Islamic State attack and told their people to stay away from the airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Poor weather conditions hamper firefighting efforts across California.
description: The Caldor fire near Sacramento has become a priority, and a new blaze, the South fire, is threatening heavily populated parts of Southern California.
content: On Wednesday, more than 14,000 firefighters were on the front lines of 12 large wildfires in California that have burned more than 1.6 million acres, fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tacey Rychter
title: Flight Attendants’ Hellish Summer: ‘I Don’t Even Feel Like a Human’
description: For cabin crews, the peak travel season has turned into a chronic battle involving frequent delays, overwork and unruly passengers that leaves them feeling battered by the public and the airlines.
content: As stranded Spirit Airlines travelers grew desperate at San Juan Airport in Puerto Rico during a chaotic night of cancellations on Aug. 1, banging on a gate door and yelling at staff, police officers rounded up the airline’s cabin crews to hide them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Stop Politicizing the Misery in Afghanistan
description: Let’s keep our bearings and humanity when discussing the botched American withdrawal.
content: Democrats are panicked that the debacle in Afghanistan will shake American voters’ confidence in not only President Biden but also the rest of the party, potentially costing it control of the Senate and the House in 2022. They’ve said as much — to me, to other journalists, to anyone who will listen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Precious Fondren
title: A Black Veteran’s Wife Feared for His Safety. Officers Fatally Shot Him.
description: Gulia Dale’s wife was concerned for his safety when she called 911, in part because he had a gun. Minutes later, he was dead.
content: The nighttime encounter lasted less than 15 seconds. When it was over, Gulia Dale III, a Black man and retired Army major, was dead, fatally shot by two white police officers responding to an emergency call from his worried wife, Karen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: N.Y.C. lays out safety measures for public schools as Delta variant rises.
description: The city’s school testing program will be smaller than last year, and only unvaccinated students will have to quarantine if exposed to the virus.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City laid out a series of long-awaited safety protocols for schools on Thursday as he seeks to reassure parents who are concerned that the Delta variant of the coronavirus will upend the school year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Celebrated String Quartet Will Disband, Ending 47-Year Run
description: The Emerson String Quartet, known for its energy and nuance, will retire in 2023 so its members can pursue solo projects.
content: The Emerson String Quartet, a renowned chamber ensemble known for its lively, nuanced playing, announced on Thursday that it would disband in 2023, after nearly a half-century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: The Education Department will wipe out $1.1 billion in debt for ITT students.
description: About 115,000 borrowers who dropped out before ITT’s 2016 collapse are eligible for debt relief and refunds.
content: In a move that will wipe out $1.1 billion in debt owed by 115,000 borrowers, the Education Department said on Thursday that it would forgive the federal loans of students who attended ITT Technical Institute but left after March 2008 without completing a degree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman
title: Yes, Marketing Is Still Sexist
description: Despite women’s progress in many parts of society, advertisements still consistently cast women as secondary.
content: — Jane Cunningham, one of the authors of “Brandsplaining: Why Marketing is (Still) Sexist And How To Fix It.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Capitol Police Officers Sue Trump and Allies Over Election Lies and Jan. 6
description: The suit, which took a broad view of the riot’s origins, was the latest effort to hold former President Donald J. Trump accountable for the Capitol attack.
content: A group of seven Capitol Police officers filed a lawsuit on Thursday accusing former President Donald J. Trump and nearly 20 members of far-right extremist groups and political organizations of a plot to disrupt the peaceful transition of power during the Capitol riot on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Ynairaly Simo Reps the Bronx (and Tweenage Zest) in ‘Vivo’
description: The 14-year-old Dominican American actress makes her big screen debut in the animated musical on Netflix, with songs by Lin-Manuel Miranda.
content: Every time Ynairaly Simo’s mother asks her what she wants to eat at home, Simo tells her the same thing: moro de guandules con bistec, or rice with pigeon peas and steak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi, Margot Sanger-Katz and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Delta’s Extra $200 Insurance Fee Shows Vaccine Dilemma for Employers
description: Charging unvaccinated workers more for health coverage may seem more appealing than a mandate but could be harder to carry out.
content: For weeks, big employers like Citigroup, Google and the Walt Disney Company have been warming to the idea of requiring coronavirus vaccines for employees. Now that one vaccine has received full federal approval, President Biden wants more to follow suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden’s Meeting With Israeli Leader Delayed After Kabul Attack
description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett’s meeting with President Biden, originally scheduled for Thursday morning, was postponed after attacks that killed American service members in Afghanistan.
content: WASHINGTON — When Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel was scheduled to meet President Biden at the White House on Thursday, the two new leaders had aimed to reset relations between their countries and reinforce a bond that has showed signs of strain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our critic recommends an ice cream competition series and a show about Norwegian vampires. And there’s a “Wicked” concert for superfans.
content: This is a preview of the Watching newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox four times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I’m in the Wedding Party. Can I Mask Up for the Ceremony?
description: A reader is worried about fulfilling her maid of honor duties, and even more worried about getting sick.
content: I am one of two maids of honor at a close friend’s upcoming wedding. Because of Covid-19 public health orders in her state, she has had to postpone the event twice. We’re finally approaching the re-rescheduled date. The couple is hosting an indoor ceremony with 200 guests (no masks or vaccination required) and a tented outdoor reception. My partner and I are traveling from California. We’re vaccinated but uncomfortable spending time indoors with others who are unmasked or potentially unvaccinated — especially when breakthrough infections are making some people very sick. Would it be tacky as a maid of honor to wear a mask throughout the evening? Will people think we’re overcautious?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘American Sausage Standoff’ Review: Order the Salad
description: This misbegotten satire about bigotry and mysterious pork products is unfunny and maladroit.
content: The far-fetched but hardly distinctive tale told in “American Sausage Standoff” is prefaced by a title card reading “This story is based on fact.” The opening shot is of a man sitting in his car while addressing the audience directly, his soothing, honey-toned voice setting the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: A large wildfire in drought-seared Minnesota threatens homes and recreation sites.
description: The Greenwood fire in the Superior National Forest has burned about 25,000 acres near the Canadian border since Aug. 15.
content: A fast-moving wildfire in the parched woodlands of northeastern Minnesota threatened cabins, homes and recreational sites on Thursday as hundreds of firefighters fought to contain it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Anti-Gay Agenda
description: It is not the gay Black person who becomes an instrument of a white supremacist attack on Black masculinity. It is the Black homophobe.
content: Why can’t straight men stop obsessing about gay people? Why is it that a thing that has nothing to do with them occupies so much of their time and energy? Maybe they should interrogate their own prurient interests in other people’s love, get at the root and figure out why the idea of male intimacy riles them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Relief, and Worry, for Arrivals From Afghanistan
description: Afghan refugees and Americans who recently made it to the Washington area are happy to be in the United States, but they fear for those left behind.
content: CHANTILLY, Va. — Thousands of Afghan refugees and Americans have arrived in the Washington region in the past few days, finding shelter and a sense of relief after shuffling from country to country and sometimes fending off violent attacks from the Taliban while fleeing Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Kamala Harris pledges U.S. help for Afghan women and children.
description: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Thursday that the United States would work with its allies to protect women and children in Afghanistan, as the Taliban takeover forced her to confront troubling historical parallels and diverted attention from her original mission on a five-day trip to Southeast Asia.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Thursday that the United States would work with its allies to protect women and children in Afghanistan, as the Taliban takeover forced her to confront troubling historical parallels and diverted attention from her original mission on a five-day trip to Southeast Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro and Joseph Goldstein
title: N.Y.C.’s Challenge: Keeping 1 Million Students Safe Amid Delta
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the school safety reopening plan on Thursday, raising questions about the city’s readiness to bring back all its students to schools next month.
content: With his time in office coming to a close, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City has staked much of his legacy on reopening schools during the pandemic, putting in-class learning at the center of his push to get the city running again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript of Biden’s Speech After Kabul Airport Attack
description: The president mourned the U.S. service members and others killed and addressed those responsible: “We will hunt you down and make you pay.”
content: The following is a transcript of President Biden’s remarks on Thursday about an attack at the Kabul, Afghanistan, airport that killed scores of people, including at least 12 U.S. service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Perlez
title: The Real Winner of the Afghan War? It’s Not Who You Think.
description: Pakistan, nominally a U.S. partner in the war, was the Afghan Taliban’s main patron, and sees the Taliban’s victory as its own. But now what does it do with its prize?
content: Just days after the Taliban took Kabul, their flag was flying high above a central mosque in Pakistan’s capital. It was an in-your-face gesture intended to spite the defeated Americans. But it was also a sign of the real victors in the 20-year Afghan war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Lauren McCarthy
title: Nebraska is recruiting unvaccinated nurses to plug a staffing shortage.
description: The state is making an unconventional attempt to fill the ranks of its health care facilities as new cases surge.
content: Health officials in Nebraska are so desperate for staff that they are recruiting unvaccinated nurses, an unconventional attempt to plug the shortage of nurses as the state battles a surge in coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: A Stranded Interpreter, and the Soldiers Who Would Not Let Go
description: Many Afghans who helped U.S. forces in Afghanistan are now in danger. One spoke to us about his battle to get his family out alive as he hid in Kabul.
content: The Americans called him “Mikey,” and as an interpreter for the Special Forces he did not just bridge language gaps. He did everything from easing negotiations with local Afghans loyal to the Taliban to warning a convoy away from an ambush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Channeling ‘Major League,’ the Orioles Snuff Out a Losing Streak
description: Burning sage, a few homers off Shohei Ohtani and an eighth-inning rally were all it took to end Baltimore’s losing streak at 19 games. Look out, A.L. East: They’ve won two in a row.
content: Sitting in his office at Camden Yards ahead of Wednesday’s game, Brandon Hyde, the manager of the Baltimore Orioles, smelled something unusual. Over the past three weeks Hyde had been consumed with ending his team’s ignominious losing streak, which had reached 19 games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: Sequins and Soul-Searching in the Competitive Dance World
description: Calls for change in this lucrative dance subculture have become broader and deeper, encompassing issues of race, gender and predatory behavior.
content: In spring, Siara Fuller, the artistic director of Charlotte Performing Arts Academy in North Carolina, brought a group of students to a dance competition in Fort Mill, S.C. It was, in many ways, an ordinary weekend within the extraordinary world of competitive dance: Hundreds of young dancers assembled at a convention center, donned glittery costumes and giant false lashes, and presented spit-polished routines for a panel of judges. (Because of Covid-19, the dancers accessorized with face masks.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Tariro Mzezewa and Jamie McGee
title: As Search for Tennessee Flood Victims Ends, a Community Grieves
description: Among the 20 people killed in racing waters were a high school freshman, an Army veteran, toddler twins and a mother of five.
content: WAVERLY, Tenn. — Joseph Prasnikar cannot escape the haunting memory of the last time he saw his wife alive: They were at home, clutched in each other’s arms, as rising water swirled around them. He slipped below the surface. When he climbed back up, she was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: After Years of Failure, California Lawmakers Pave the Way for More Housing
description: To ease an affordability crisis, the Legislature voted to open suburbs to development, allowing two-units on lots long reserved for single-family homes.
content: California needs more housing. More condominiums, more townhouses near mass transit, more suburban apartment buildings. There is no other solution to the state’s desperate homelessness problem and a deepening housing affordability crisis, according to a broad collection of economists and housing experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Populist Hero or Demagogue: Who Is Tunisia’s President?
description: As a law professor, Kais Saied preached strict adherence to the Constitution. As Tunisia’s president, he has bent it to his will. Will he save Tunisia’s democracy or destroy it?
content: TUNIS — Year after year, the man now accused of trashing Tunisia’s Constitution sat straight-backed in a suit and tie at the front of a university lecture hall, his notes on constitutional law tidy in front of him, his Day 1 warning to students ensuring pin-drop silence:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: Politico Is Sold to Axel Springer for More Than $1 Billion
description: The publishing giant will take control of Politico, Politico Europe and Politico’s tech news site, Protocol.
content: Politico, the Washington news site that has prospered for years as Beltway professionals gobbled up its scoops and inside-baseball-style reporting, will have a new owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: What Was on the Best-Seller List 20 Years Ago?
description: A peek into the archives reveals that popular books from early September 2001 were both prescient and timeless.
content: IN RETROSPECT For two decades, it’s bothered me that I can’t remember what I bought at Borders in the shopping concourse under the World Trade Center on Sept. 10, 2001. Was it a novel? A box of thank you notes? A copy of “Chicka Chicka Boom Boom” for my daughter? I do recall being slightly disdainful of that outpost of the now-defunct chain; it lacked the panache of its downtown compatriots — the wild sprawl of the Strand, the intellectual superiority of the late, great St. Marks Bookshop, the tweedy intimacy of Three Lives. And the next day, it was gone. I delved into the Book Review archives to see what might have appeared in Borders’ windows in those final weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Kasulis Cho
title: In This Remote American Outpost, Pandemic Recovery Is a Faraway Dream
description: Tourism-dependent Guam has done almost everything it can to restart its economy. Its Asian neighbors may have to bounce back first.
content: TAMUNING, Guam — Perched steps away from the prismatic seas off Guam’s western shore, a water sports shop sat shuttered on a recent weekend morning, its rack of neon kayaks and fleet of Jet Skis collecting fallen leaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: One Way to Run
description: Ashish Vengsarkar sets a slow and steady rhythm for our solve.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Ashish Vengsarkar has recently returned to the constructing fold after a 10-year hiatus, and I, for one, am glad to see it. His puzzles are creative and delightful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Michael Morgan, Adventurous Oakland Maestro, Dies at 63
description: As music director of the Oakland Symphony, he sought diversity in his audiences as well as in his programming.
content: Michael Morgan, the music director of the Oakland Symphony, who in his 30 years in that post sought to bring orchestral music to a broader audience, particularly young people and people of color, died on Aug. 20 in Oakland, Calif. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Illinois will require masks indoors for everyone and educators must get shots or face testing.
description: All state residents 2 and older will need to wear masks inside. Students and staff at public schools already have to wear masks.
content: CHICAGO — Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois announced on Thursday a new, stricter set of coronavirus restrictions, ordering a statewide indoor mask mandate and requiring that all educators be vaccinated or face regular testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: In a twist, China’s delay in approving BioNTech’s vaccine could help Taiwan.
description: Taiwan’s nettlesome relationship with China caused the self-governing island to struggle for months to acquire doses of BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine before a deal was finally reached in July.
content: Taiwan’s nettlesome relationship with China caused the self-governing island to struggle for months to acquire doses of BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine before a deal was finally reached in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Summer Squash Has the Range
description: Three recipes for zucchini celebrate the versatility of this seasonal staple.
content: I was stunned by the summer squash at the market this weekend — table after table of long, yellow and green zucchini with drooping, shaggy blossoms still attached; tiny patty pans, dimpled all the way around; and lumpy tangles of goosenecks. I went for some shiny-skinned zucchini, and have been eating them raw, cooked and extremely cooked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Delta Makes the Unvaccinated Pay
description: Insurance surcharges, like the one announced by Delta Air Lines, are a new front in corporate coronavirus vaccine initiatives.
content: Delta Air Lines has opened a new front in the push by companies to get employees vaccinated against the coronavirus. Yesterday, Delta said that workers who aren’t vaccinated by Nov. 1 will have to pay an additional $200 per month to remain on the airline’s health plan. More companies are considering imposing such fees on the unvaccinated, following the airline’s lead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Forbes plans to go public in a $630 million SPAC deal.
description: The publication, owned by Integrated Whale Media and the Forbes family, reached an agreement to merge with Magnum Opus Acquisition, a publicly traded blank-check firm.
content: Forbes announced on Thursday that it planned to go public through a deal with a special-purpose acquisition company, or SPAC.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Maggie Nelson Is Drawn to Certain Autobiographies
description: “I have a soft spot for books by tough, radically honest women with an uncommon antenna for magic, language and landscape.”
content: “I have a soft spot for books by tough, radically honest women with an uncommon antenna for magic, language and landscape,” says Maggie Nelson, the author, most recently, of “On Freedom: Four Songs of Care and Constraint.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are in Carnegie Hill, Downtown Brooklyn and the Concourse neighborhood.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: He Passed Out Three Times in 10 Days. What Was Wrong?
description: Could all this really be a result of a urinary-tract infection?
content: The 75-year-old man lay sprawled on the floor between the kitchen counter and the island, surrounded by a halo of pills. “What happened?” his wife asked as she hurried to his side, although she suspected she already knew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: President Biden condemns terrorist attack and vows to hunt down those responsible.
description: Mr. Biden said he had asked his commanders to find ways to target ISIS-K, the Afghan affiliate of the Islamic State, which claimed responsibility for the attacks earlier in the day.
content: President Biden on Thursday denounced a terrorist attack at the Kabul airport that killed at least 13 American service members and injured 18 more, saying that the frantic evacuation of U.S. citizens and allies from Afghanistan will continue even as he pledged to hunt down those responsible for the attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: How Government Decisions Left Tennessee Exposed to Deadly Flooding
description: Choices about building rules, insurance programs, flood maps and more put residents at higher risk, according to climate and disaster experts.
content: The floods that killed at least 20 people in Tennessee last weekend arrived with shocking speed and force — seemingly a case study of the difficulties of protecting people from explosive rainstorms as climate change gets worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rachel Quester, Dave Shaw, Larissa Anderson, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Biden’s Border Dilemma
description: Increased crossings from Central America are forcing the administration to choose between two major goals — stopping migrants or stopping the root causes.
content: Early on in the Biden administration, it rolled out a two-pronged migration plan — a reversal of the most punitive elements of Donald Trump’s policy and a commitment to rooting out the causes of migration from Central America, namely corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: An Afghan competing in Tokyo’s Paralympics finds solace in swimming.
description: TOKYO — The first time Abbas Karimi jumped into a pool, the water brought fresh relief from the heat of Kabul, the Afghan capital.
content: TOKYO — The first time Abbas Karimi jumped into a pool, the water brought fresh relief from the heat of Kabul, the Afghan capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Bernard
title: Willie Norris Has Some Words for Us
description: A Brooklyn designer with many messages (and many different kinds of fans).
content: The fashion designer Willie Norris has two fan bases who are apt to recognize her in her Brooklyn neighborhood, show her that they are wearing clothes she designed, and possibly shed tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Justice Dept. to Close Troubled Jail Where Jeffrey Epstein Died
description: The 233 people being held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center will be moved, at least temporarily, while officials address conditions there.
content: Conditions at a high-security federal jail in Lower Manhattan have deteriorated so much that federal officials said on Thursday that they planned to close the facility, at least temporarily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Republicans are divided over how to handle Afghan evacuees.
description: The resettlement of Afghan allies in the U.S. is exposing an internal divide between the Republican Party’s anti-immigrant wing and conservatives who want to help the refugees.
content: The resettlement of Afghan allies in the U.S. is exposing an internal divide between the Republican Party’s anti-immigrant wing and conservatives who want to help the refugees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: 2021 U.S. Open: Draw Reveals Novak Djokovic’s Path to a Grand Slam
description: The only men besides Djokovic who have won Grand Slam singles titles are Marin Cilic and Andy Murray, but the women’s draw is brimming with major singles champions.
content: Novak Djokovic has chased down all manner of records on his way to becoming one of the greatest tennis players ever. But he has never been on a tennis treasure hunt quite like this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Let’s Not Pretend That the Way We Withdrew From Afghanistan Was the Problem
description: Our ignominious exit reflects the failure of America’s foreign policy establishment at both prediction and policymaking.
content: In 2005, two of my colleagues at The American Prospect, Sam Rosenfeld and Matt Yglesias, wrote an essay I think about often. It was called “The Incompetence Dodge,” and it argued that American policymakers and pundits routinely try to rescue the reputation of bad ideas by attributing their failure to poor execution. At the time, they were writing about the liberal hawks who were blaming the catastrophe of the Iraq war on the Bush administration’s maladministration rather than rethinking the enterprise in its totality. But the same dynamic suffuses the recriminations over the Afghanistan withdrawal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Albums to Hear Right Now
description: Yo-Yo Ma’s Beethoven and a young star soprano’s Sibelius are among the highlights of recent recordings.
content: This dashing album has been my introduction to the composer Jean-Baptiste Senaillé — well loved by the French aristocracy in the early 18th century, but now an obscurity — as well as to the young violinist Théotime Langlois de Swarte.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: When the Dixie Fire Threatened Home
description: As flames approached her family’s hometown in California, a reporter who normally works in New York knew she could lend a hand.
content: Annie Correal reports on immigrant communities for The Times’s Metro desk. But lately, her byline has appeared above coverage of the Dixie fire in Northern California, currently the largest wildfire in the country. Ms. Correal has close family ties to the Indian Valley, a ranching area in the Sierra Nevada threatened by the flames. A week ago, she boarded a plane to lend her local expertise to the National desk. In a recent article, she tells a personal story about a group of people defending their homes. Ms. Correal reflected on the assignment in an interview. Her edited responses are below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: A New Coal Mine for England Is Stirring Hopes and Fears
description: A mining company’s proposal has largely been embraced locally as an economic stimulus, but climate concerns may shelve the idea.
content: WHITEHAVEN, England — Britain has been getting out of the coal business for the past 100 years. The fuel that turned an island nation into a black-skied manufacturing giant during the Industrial Revolution has steadily been replaced by oil, natural gas and, increasingly in recent years, offshore winds and the rays of the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: At Rockaway, Dancing for the Sea, the Sky, the Sand and the Birds
description: This season, Beach Sessions has just one dance: “Repose,” a meditative, durational work by Moriah Evans.
content: “The beach is a moody place, you know?” the choreographer Moriah Evans said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Kamala Harris, in Southeast Asia and in Uniform
description: The vice president’s solo international trip set a tone, and a standard.
content: Any solo international trip of the first female vice president of the United States and the country’s first female vice president of color would, in normal circumstances, invite first-degree scrutiny. Not just of her speeches and joint news conferences, but of her ceremonial appearances. Emphasis on the last word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: He’s Still Fighting Developers for the Park His Father Founded
description: A large, contaminated tract of Liberty State Park in New Jersey will be cleaned and cleared for trails, sports fields and wetlands.
content: On a warm July evening, Sam Pesin stooped to fetch a plastic bag and a tangled Mylar balloon as he wandered through Liberty State Park in New Jersey, stuffing both in his back pocket. When he saw the driver of an ice cream truck, he asked him to arrive early to that night’s free concert because the empanada truck couldn’t make it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Kacey Musgraves’s Expanding Universe
description: After two wry country albums and a Grammy-sweeping breakthrough, pop stardom is calling for Kacey Musgraves. Will she answer?
content: NASHVILLE — Kacey Musgraves made her new album in a garage studio buzzing with domestic chaos. On an August afternoon, the 33-year-old singer and songwriter arrived there to find a basketball rolled into the driveway, tiny swimsuits drying on the porch and a spaniel, Bean, rooting around the percussion section for a stick. “I don’t feel self-conscious out here,” Musgraves said, leaning into a snug couch next to a Himalayan salt lamp. “You can try stuff and if it sucks, it’s fine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Dozens killed in Kabul attack.
content: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for two suicide bombings outside Hamid Karzai International Airport that killed scores of Afghan civilians and at least 12 American service members. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 19 New Books Coming in September
description: The month brims with memoirs, histories and new novels, from Colson Whitehead, Sally Rooney, Liane Moriarty, Anthony Doerr, Gayl Jones and more.
content: This new thriller, from the author of “Big Little Lies” and “Nine Perfect Strangers,” follows the Delaneys, a family headed by two aging tennis stars. Stan and Joy have sold their renowned tennis academy and are hoping to relax — until Joy suddenly vanishes. As the family works to figure out who might have wished to harm her — one of Stan’s former protégés? a mysterious woman who takes shelter at the Delaneys’ home?— their secrets and tensions boil over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Ziegler
title: Texas Has Cleared a Path to the End of Roe v. Wade
description: Justices fearing a backlash might not be ready to overturn the ruling. But Texas offers a way to restrict abortion further.
content: A major confrontation on the abortion battlefield looms this fall, when the Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments on whether Mississippi can ban abortion after 15 weeks. That’s roughly nine weeks before viability, the point at which states are now allowed to forbid abortion. To uphold Mississippi’s law, the court would have to eliminate its own viability rule or reverse Roe v. Wade altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Isabella’ Review: Audition of a Lifetime
description: The Argentine filmmaker Matías Piñeiro, who riffs on Shakespeare, expands his ambition with this drama.
content: The New York-based Argentine filmmaker Matías Piñeiro has carved out an exclusive niche: Each of his fractured, low-stakes narratives is tied to a different Shakespeare play. His last feature, “Hermia & Helena,” involved a Spanish translation of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” His latest, “Isabella,” revolves around two actresses, Mariel (María Villar) and Luciana (Agustina Muñoz), auditioning for the part of Isabella in “Measure for Measure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Stephen Castle
title: Chicken, Milkshakes, Candy: Scarce in Britain’s Truck Driver Shortage
description: Because of Brexit and other reasons, Britain doesn’t have enough truck drivers, and that’s causing all sorts of items to go vanish from stores and restaurants.
content: Across Britain, a slow-burning problem has ignited into a supply chain crisis in recent weeks as restaurants, supermarkets and food manufacturers warned customers that some popular products may be temporarily unavailable because of a shortage of truck drivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Inge Ginsberg, Holocaust Survivor With a Heavy Metal Coda, Dies at 99
description: Her rich life, spanning three continents and 11 decades, entailed wartime espionage, volumes of poetry, songwriting and a late-career turn as a rock band’s frontwoman.
content: Inge Ginsberg, who fled the Holocaust, helped American spies in Switzerland during World War II, wrote songs in Hollywood and, in a final assertion of her presence on earth, made a foray into heavy metal music as a nonagenarian, died on July 20 in a care home in Zurich. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Afghanistan, Tennessee, U.S. Open: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: The Dream May Be Over for the Grand Prospect Hall
description: The Grand Prospect Hall, a Brooklyn icon that was built 129 years ago and made famous by its eccentric TV commercials, has a new owner who wants to demolish it.
content: For almost 40 years, New Yorkers knew the Grand Prospect Hall by one simple phrase: “We make your dreams come true!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Why House Democrats Face ‘Mutually Assured Destruction’
description: Progressive and moderate Democrats are in a standoff over the party’s major bills — and each side has leverage over the other at the same time.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Is There a Nuclear Option for Stopping Climate Change?
description: Once the bête noire of environmentalists, nuclear power is now being hailed by some as a solution to a warming world.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Amsterdam’s Mayor Announces Talks With Jewish Heirs on Kandinsky Claim
description: The city council will be asked to approve any agreement between the mayor and the heirs to turn over a painting, owned by a Jewish couple before the 1940 Nazi invasion.
content: The mayor of Amsterdam announced on Thursday that she had begun discussions to turn over a painting by the Russian abstract artist Wassily Kandinsky to the heirs of a Jewish couple who had owned the work before the Nazi takeover of the Netherlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: How a Defunct Federal Provision Helped Pave the Way for New Voting Restrictions
description: Curbs on drop boxes, tougher ID requirements and purges of voter rolls would have been weakened, or never even passed, if a federal oversight system had been in place.
content: Georgia toughened identification requirements for absentee voting. Arizona authorized removing voters from the rolls if they do not cast a ballot at least once every two years. Florida and Georgia cut back sharply the use of drop boxes for mail-in ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A Taliban leader says the group wants to forget the past, but describes restrictions.
content: In his first sit-down interview with a Western media outlet since the Taliban took full control of Afghanistan, Zabihullah Mujahid — seen as likely to be the future minister of information and culture — said the group wants to “forget what happened in the past” and rejected widespread fears that the Taliban are already exacting vengeance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Serena Williams and Her Fellow Tennis Greats Are Limping Toward the Exits
description: Graceful final chapters in tennis can be difficult to achieve, as Serena Williams and Roger Federer are learning firsthand.
content: Serena Williams’s announcement of her withdrawal from the U.S. Open included 78 words and a heart emoji.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: In a German first, Hamburg will allow merchants to insist on vaccinations.
description: BERLIN — In what is a first in Germany, the city state of Hamburg will allow restaurants, hairdressers, clubs and religious institutions to bar entry to unvaccinated adults or those who have not built up immunity through a Covid infection. The businesses can then forego strict limits on indoor seating, dancing and mandatory minimum distancing requirements.
content: BERLIN — In what is a first in Germany, the city state of Hamburg will allow restaurants, hairdressers, clubs and religious institutions to bar entry to unvaccinated adults or those who have not built up immunity through a Covid infection. The businesses can then forego strict limits on indoor seating, dancing and mandatory minimum distancing requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The New Chief Chaplain at Harvard? An Atheist.
description: The elevation of Greg Epstein, author of “Good Without God,” reflects a broader trend of young people who increasingly identify as spiritual but religiously nonaffiliated.
content: The Puritan colonists who settled in New England in the 1630s had a nagging concern about the churches they were building: How would they ensure that the clergymen would be literate? Their answer was Harvard University, a school that was established to educate the ministry and adopted the motto “Truth for Christ and the Church.” It was named after a pastor, John Harvard, and it would be more than 70 years before the school had a president who was not a clergyman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos and Mike Baker
title: Facing Its Worst Virus Surge, Oregon Returns to Strict Mandates
description: The National Guard has been deployed. Health care workers are pleading for help. Now the state is ordering masks for everyone who gathers closely in public, even outdoors.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Facing a 990 percent increase in coronavirus hospitalizations since July 9, Oregon leaders have deployed the National Guard to hospitals, dispatched crisis teams to the hardest-hit regions of the state and ordered educators and health care workers to get vaccinated or lose their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serhiy Zhadan and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: Headphones
description: Bob Holman calls Serhiy Zhadan’s poetry a “Canterbury Tales” of Ukrainian common people.
content: Bob Holman calls Serhiy Zhadan’s poetry a “Canterbury Tales” of Ukrainian common people. He lists all the people, the soldiers, farmers, drug dealers and poor whose stories Zhadan tells. The list goes on until it includes everyone. How could it not? These poems were crafted in a world that frightens — where the desire to be free leads to an accumulation of corpses, where no matter what, you must still sing and still love. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: From Mexico to Colombia to the West Indies to a farm in England’s Lake District, the books we recommend this week largely cast their eyes far from the United States. We like two novels set in Mexico City — one a noir, the other a recursive stream-of-consciousness monologue — along with a look at Osama bin Laden’s life and death, a Colombian story collection, a historical novel about an unlikely entrepreneur in 18th-century Montserrat, and the biography of an American woman who helped organize resistance to Hitler in 1930s Berlin. That English farm? It belongs to the shepherd and author James Rebanks, whose new book is all about the challenges of sustainable agriculture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Two of Bank of America’s Post-Crisis Leaders Will Retire
description: Vice Chair Anne Finucane, one of the most powerful women in banking, will leave at the end of the year. So will the chief operating officer, Thomas K. Montag.
content: Two towering figures who helped steer Bank of America out of the financial crisis more than a decade ago will retire at the end of the year, the bank said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Diego Luna Said Hello to Directing TV With a Show About Goodbyes
description: “Everything Will Be Fine,” on Netflix, follows the dissolution — and the new beginnings — of a modern family. For Luna, it was about “making sure we are in charge of deciding what family should be for us.”
content: This interview contains spoilers for “Todo Va a Estar Bien.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik, Matthieu Aikins and Julian E. Barnes
title: Scenes of chaos after blasts rock area around Kabul airport.
description: In one split instant, unspeakably bad somehow found a way to become even worse when terrorists targeted the crowds outside an Afghan airport.
content: For more than a week, the roadways outside the Kabul airport had been a scene of desperation and chaos, but in a single instant Thursday, unspeakably bad somehow found a way to become even worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Ni Mi Madre’ Review: A Son’s Stinging Tribute to His Mother
description: Arturo Luís Soria wrote and stars in a forgiving, yet cleareyed solo show about parental damage done.
content: Enter the playwright, bare-chested and barefoot in a white skirt that skims the floor. Then the skirt becomes an off-the-shoulder dress, and he becomes his mother, in an exuberant dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: California Could Throw Away What It’s Won
description: A crazy recall process could lead to repudiation of the state's policy successes.
content: If you live in California and haven’t yet voted or made plans to vote on the proposed recall of Gov. Gavin Newsom, please wake up. This is a situation in which apathy could have awesome consequences: California, which isn’t as liberal a state as you may imagine but is nonetheless considerably more liberal than the nation as a whole, may be about to absent-mindedly acquire a Trumpist governor who could never win a normal election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
title: Israel’s Spy Agency Snubbed the U.S. Can Trust Be Restored?
description: Israel’s new prime minister, Naftali Bennett, heads to Washington promising better relations and seeking support for covert attacks on Iran’s nuclear program.
content: WASHINGTON — The cable sent this year by the outgoing C.I.A. officer in charge of building spy networks in Iran reverberated throughout the intelligence agency’s Langley headquarters, officials say: America’s network of informers had largely been lost to Tehran’s brutally efficient counterintelligence operations, which has stymied efforts to rebuild it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Olivier Sarkozy’s Turtle Bay Townhouse Is Listed for $11.5 Million
description: The half brother of the former French president was renovating the house with the fashion designer Mary-Kate Olsen before they divorced earlier this year.
content: After Olivier Sarkozy bought a combined townhouse at 226-228 East 49th Street in the Turtle Bay neighborhood of Manhattan in April 2014, and shortly before he married Mary-Kate Olsen in November 2015, the couple kicked off what was supposed to be an ambitious, top-to-bottom renovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Breakthrough Covid Cases: Uncommon and Often Mild, but Not Always
description: Vaccination remains the best defense, health experts say. But some infections occur regardless, and can come as a traumatic surprise.
content: For Moira Smith and her mother, July promised a glimmer of normalcy after months of isolation. The two flew from Alaska to Houston and visited family, celebrating the first birthday of their cousin’s granddaughter. Ms. Smith’s mother bought a patterned pink onesie to give as a gift, and they all snapped photos of the baby’s face smeared with chocolate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: After a shift to video, Vice Media lays off writers.
description: The company cut nearly 20 staff members at Vice and Refinery29.
content: A month ago, Vice Media announced a plan to reduce the number of text articles it publishes on Vice.com, Refinery29 and other Vice-owned sites by 40 to 50 percent as the company shifts its emphasis to video. On Thursday, Vice Media laid off more than a dozen employees, many of them writers and text editors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. official warns of ISIS threat as ‘clock continues to tick down’ on flights out.
description: Britain said on Thursday that it had credible intelligence of a likely terrorist attack in Afghanistan within “hours,” urging those trying to flee the country to stay away from the Kabul airport even as it acknowledged that the window was closing for its evacuation operation.
content: Britain said on Thursday that it had credible intelligence of a likely terrorist attack in Afghanistan within “hours,” urging those trying to flee the country to stay away from the Kabul airport even as it acknowledged that the window was closing for its evacuation operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: How G.M.’s First Turbo Engines Crashed and Burned
description: Oldsmobile and Chevrolet pioneered the technology for mass-market cars, but the turbos flopped — and took decades to gain acceptance.
content: In 1962, rival divisions inside General Motors — Oldsmobile and Chevrolet — concluded a furious intramural race to build an advanced engine using battle-proven technology used in World War II fighter planes. This technology boosted both engine power and gas mileage. It also pointed the way for Detroit to break its addiction to ever larger gas-guzzling engines by getting more power from lighter, more efficient motors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Limited-Edition Comic Books for Children Getting Vaccinated
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said that unvaccinated people accounted for over 95 percent of all the city’s Covid-19 hospitalizations.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

author: By Ben Hubbard, Eric Schmitt and Matthew Rosenberg
title: After Decades of War, ISIS and Al Qaeda Can Still Wreak Havoc
description: The U.S. and its allies waged war for 20 years to try to defeat terrorists in Afghanistan. A double-suicide bombing demonstrated that they remain a threat.
content: DOHA, Qatar — The nightmare that kept counterterrorism experts awake even before the Taliban returned to power is that Afghanistan would become fertile ground for terrorist groups, most notably Al Qaeda and the Islamic State.
source.name: The New York Times

title: August Subscriber Digest
description: Stories popular with subscribers, curated by Times editors. Subscriber-exclusive features.

title: New York’s Legendary Literary Hangouts
description: James Baldwin drank at the White Horse Tavern. Dorothy Parker lunched at the Algonquin. Arthur C. Clark lived and wrote at the Chelsea Hotel. Take a spin through a century of writer’s hangouts.
content: James Baldwin drank at the White Horse Tavern. Dorothy Parker lunched at the Algonquin. Arthur C. Clark lived and wrote at the Chelsea Hotel. Take a spin through a century of writer’s hangouts.

title: Where Suicide Bombers Struck at the Kabul Airport
description: Images taken hours before the attacks show the desperate and crowded conditions that made the Abbey Gate a vulnerable target.
content: Images taken hours before the attacks show the desperate and crowded conditions that made the Abbey Gate a vulnerable target.

author: By Ross Mantle and Heather Murphy
title: How to Paint 50,000 Miles of Lines
description: Thermoplastic, tiny glass beads and “bike dude” stencils are all part of this essential, but rarely considered craft.
content: Thermoplastic, tiny glass beads and “bike dude” stencils are all part of this essential, but rarely considered craft.

author: By Lazaro Gamio and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: Where the Delta Wave Has Driven Up Covid-19 Vaccinations
description: Vaccine uptake has risen from early-summer lows all over the United States, and the upswing is especially pronounced in places that have been hit the hardest by the pandemic’s fourth wave.
content: Vaccine uptake has risen from early-summer lows all over the United States, and the upswing is especially pronounced in places that have been hit the hardest by the pandemic’s fourth wave.

title: A First-Time Buyer Took His $500,000 to the Upper West Side. Which Home Would You Choose?
description: After fleeing the city during the pandemic, a longtime renter returned with a mission to buy a co-op in his favorite neighborhood. But what could he afford in one of Manhattan’s priciest areas?
content: After fleeing the city during the pandemic, a longtime renter returned with a mission to buy a co-op in his favorite neighborhood. But what could he afford in one of Manhattan’s priciest areas?

description: I gained access to the animatronic inner sanctum. Here’s what I saw.

title: At Least 250,000 Afghans Who Worked With U.S. Haven’t Been Evacuated, Estimates Say
description: The current pace of evacuations is far too slow to rescue Afghans who may be eligible for special U.S. visas before Americans leave, estimates suggest.
content: The current pace of evacuations is far too slow to rescue Afghans who may be eligible for special U.S. visas before Americans leave, estimates suggest.

description: The Pentagon said at least 13 U.S. service members were killed and 15 wounded in the attack near an airport gate on Thursday. Scores of Afghan civilians were killed and wounded.

title: Corrections: Aug. 26, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 26, 2021.
content: An article on Monday about flooding in Tennessee misspelled the name of a 15-year-old girl missing since the flood. She is Lilly Bryant, not Lily.
